author: rootsid
title: RootsWallet - Support for sidetree
description: RootsWallet, that initially supports Prism DIDs, needs to support as many DID methods as possible to reach global interoperability

f6_assessments.q0:
This project chose, among other areas, interoperability as the primary goal for their Roots Wallet, which meets the stated goals of the Challenge Setting. The problem and solution statements are written as asked. Voters will find the Impact statement clear and concise––the highest achievement for the design of any proposal aside from funding itself.
 
It should be stated that this CA has a background in SSI environments and is well versed with Atala PRISM. Thus, my experience means I’m qualified to be duly impressed by the work the team has done thus far. They met in the Plutus Pioneer program and accomplished 2 separate funded projects (that are all part of RootsWallet––the product they are still perfecting with this proposal) over the past 2 funded rounds. The further development with the RootsWallet (who’s growth is truly organic in nature, around the work of others in the space that they have wisely used as a way of understanding their own path forward) is an actual value add for the Cardano ecosystem as it gives real life to the SSI environment on its Sidetree nodes.

At the risk of redundancy, it should be said that the work of this proposal is undoubtedly designed to build a foundation for further scaling. Thus, preparing RootsWallet to meet tomorrow’s challenges through the work of making it interoperable.
f6_assessments.q1:
The plan is thorough and uses a proven method (Agile methodology) that the team is well familiar with. One team member will execute the total 76 hours of work (at a rate of $100/hour––fair for the field). His experience and capacity are well documented in the proposal, leaving no doubt of his capabilities (added to that is his proven track record from work on past funded rounds). Contingencies are already planned (an actual “plan b” and “plan c”) in case they are not able to do the work alone. Because of this, the potential for success seems highly likely, and both the timetable and budget reflect clear, well-thought-out details that satisfies the rigor of this CA.

The plan shows what work will be done and precisely how that will take place in its “high-level scope of each activity…” section in Feasibility. Further, all resources necessary are accounted for (essentially the funding and the alternative plans for completion if necessary).
f6_assessments.q2:
The roadmap is well laid, and the time horizon for the 6-week project is thoughtfully planned. The work being done can all be tracked on GitHub (link provided in the proposal). Thus, all metrics and KPIs are sufficient to meet the requirements of a Catalyst proposal. The completion of the two deliverables––open-source code for RootsWallet and the documentation of usage in the public repository––are the measurement of success used to verify completion.

In its success statement, the proposal again addresses the problem and solution in a well-summarized statement. Voters should have no issue following this well-written, exemplary proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a key continuation of work begun in earlier funds to help deliver an SSI constellation of tools to the Cardano ecosystem.  In particular this is the continued development of an interoperability protocol, in the form of straight software development, so that something like HyperledgerIndy can interoperate with PRISM (specifically the did:ada call method).  Interoperability is not only key to Cardano adoption going forward, but critical to the overall opensource framework within which SSI must function.  Linux Foundation's Indy is the leader in the space, so this kind of connection is critical, especially if one takes into account the potential opportunities arising from DIDcomm (another project integration the RootsID team is pursuing) and the ability to have peer to peer relationships across platforms.  This specific piece of software is meant to bring together multiple operations, including the existing wallet code and the cardano sidetree plugin.  One by one the pieces of the first Sovrin style SSI platform are falling into place for this team.
f6_assessments.q1: This is a straightforward software sprint and that is reflected in the modest budget and rapid 6 week timeline.  All of the relevant githubs have been helpfully linked up in the overview of the project and the Agile sprints have already been mapped (but not described) in this projects Github.  It is ready to go with a detailed plan of action.  The proposer notes the only real risk as a possible shortage of time, or competing projects, but with the timeline for this so clearly outlined and the backing of the team behind RootsID (plus the ability to pull more cohorts from fellow graduates of the AtalaPRISMPioneeers course) I have no doubt that this project can be fit into the schedule.
f6_assessments.q2: This is an opensource project being fully implemented in Github, so the ability to create issues (community tracking and concerns) monitor the project planning kanban (auditing oversight) and to see the total commits and completed repos (deliverables) gives high confidence that this project can stay on track.  In the end, this project will be filing its completion report within weeks of first funding, so the audit burden is utterly minimal.

f6_assessments.q0: I agree that this proposal thoroughly addresses the challenge. The proposal seeks to provide the first open source wallet on Cardano which supports Decentralized ID and allows interoperability.  This is in line with both the challenge goals, and Cardano's mission of providing decentralized identity solutions.
f6_assessments.q1:
Developer's identity is public and is part of a doxxed team. From the experience side I feel confident about the dev's ability to complete the goals of the proposal.

As to the plan, the allocation of funds is clearly thoroughly explained, down to hourly costs. Budget breakdown seems reasonable given developer's experience and time allocated. 

Developer sights they may have time constraints which prevent them from being able to commit the project in time, however they seem to have reasonable plans in place to mitigate this risk.
f6_assessments.q2:
The goals are clearly detailed to the community and all code is viewable in a public repository. 

The timeline of 6 weeks is clearly broken down and easy to follow, and there is little reason to doubt that deadlines will not be met based on previous track record.

Moreover, the proposal is a continuation of two previously funded projects which increases overall confidence in auditability.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a useful addition to the RootsWallet project, to increase interoperability with DID frameworks other than Atala PRISM -- specifically, the DIF Sidetree DID protocol. The RootsWallet is a crucial tool for the Cardano SSI ecosystem, and this is a straightforward enhancement to it. This is directly related to the goal of the challenge.

I am qualified to give this assessment as a funded Catalyst proposer (F6 and F7) on identity / authentication.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer is developing an excellent track record building identity solutions for Catalyst, including the sidetree-cardano project for which a Github repo is provided. There is a sufficiently detailed technical plan for the proposal. Although the proposer notes that he is resource/time-constrained for delivering the proposal, he has a good record of delivery on previous projects. For these reasons, I strongly agree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer correctly notes that this is a software development project that will be assessed in terms of its deliverables, and that standard development tools can track the progress of development. I strongly agree that these methods are sufficient to audit the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Decentralized ID is one of the key infrastructures in a greater aspiration Cardano trying to achieve as an ecosystem. It will eliminate single point of centralized entities that proven crucial for implementations and applications to be as decentralized as possible. Interoperability is also extremely essential and vital since multiple DID will pose some issues and make the reality fragmented by having multiple roots of trust. I believe this proposal is trying to address a real issue that interconnected with the overall impact.
f6_assessments.q1: No flaw so far in this particular aspect. Proposer mentioned the technicalities well with solid explanation of timed roadmap and actionable plans. Duration is highly attainable and budget is clear and efficient. Rodolfo also has great track record himself while also being well-tenured and well equipped with decent and adequate capabilities and expertise to deliver this project. The only risk he mentioned about personal time management but measures and helps have been derived to manage it. No technical risk he mentioned also boosted my conviction.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs are well defined and Sprint methodology is an industry standard on such development. Rodolfo’s github and social media are open to public so everyone can check his progress and verify the contributions. Furthermore, this project being open-source is very helpful to the larger community to build and maintain its development in sustainable manner.

solution: We will continue improving our Open Source RootsWallet by adding interoperability with sidetree-cardano Decentralized Identity method.
experience: The team is fully engaged on Self-Sovereign Identity projects in the Cardano community with several projects already funded and delivered on F6 and F7. They built RootsWallet, the first open source Identity wallet for Prism, and a Universal Resolver Plugin for sidetree-cardano.
